awd_titl_txt: Rigidity in von Neumann Algebras: Connections and Applications to Orbit Equivalence, Geometric Group Theory, and Continuous Model Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of von Neumann algebras began in efforts to understand particle physics but subsequently became an independent discipline that has stimulated the development of powerful mathematical theories, bringing valuable insight to other areas of physics (statistical mechanics), biology (DNA structure), and engineering (cell-phone design). This project further advances research in this field and is expected to reveal new applications and establish new bridges to other areas in mathematics (ergodic theory, group theory, logic, and probability). The activities of this project provide ample dissertation subject matter for three graduate students who are involved in the research.

This research project explores new boundaries and technical inputs in deformation/rigidity theory towards the classification of von Neumann algebras arising from groups and their actions on probability spaces. The project targets the following specific themes: find new natural examples of actions of groups on probability spaces that are remembered by their von Neumann algebras; construct the first examples of property (T) groups that can be reconstructed from their von Neumann algebras; investigate the structure of von Neumann algebras arising from mapping class groups and outer automorphisms of free groups; find new invariants to classify ultrapowers of factors and explore in depth their applications to continuous model theory. To achieve these goals the principal investigator will develop new methods to implement algebraic, cohomological, geometric, and dynamical information about a group and its actions into the analytic framework of von Neumann algebras. In addition, the project pursues new analytic tools towards the calculation of the symmetry groups of ultrapower factors. The results arising from this project are expected to reveal significant new applications and connections to representation theory, geometric group theory, orbit equivalence, and logic.

por.por_cntn:
In his attempt to provide a rigorous mathematical formalism for quantum mechanics, John von Neumann introduced in mid-thirties a category of new mathematical objects now known as von Neuman algebras. Soon it was realized that von Neumann algebras display an incredibly rich structure, their study becoming a stand-alone discipline, with deep connections with other areas of Mathematics, significantly group theory and ergodic theory. This is best illustrated by an early fundamental result asserting that groups and their actions on spaces naturally give rise in natural way to so-called group von Neumann algebras. Ever since their introduction, classifying these von Neumann algebras in terms of their group/actions initial data has emerged as a major direction of research in this area and generated overtime a spectacular progress and development of exciting theories. 

The introduction of Popa's deformation/rigidity theory, twenty years ago, completely revolutionized the study of von Neumann algebras by providing solutions to many long-standing open problems and initiating new avenues of research. This novel approach provided the necessary technical framework for the study of the so-called rigidity phenomena in the context of von Neumann algebras. In Mathematics, rigidity is the condition that allows one to recognize the entire structure of an object, just from limited a priori information.  

Innovating the prior technology in deformation/rigidity theory, the PI and his collaborators found novel ways to detect certain algebraic, geometric and cohomological properties of groups from the analytic setting of their von Neumann algebras. Consequently, the PI identified a host of new groups and algebraic group features that are entirely recognizable from their von Neumann algebras; this was one of the core directions of the proposed project. Some of these methods and results allowed the PI and his collaborators to distinguish between the von Neumann algebras of property (T) groups and compute some of their invariants, thus advancing some older questions of Fields Medalist, A. Connes. These results unveiled new rigidity phenomena which have deep consequences to the current understanding of the structure of von Neumann algebras. In addition, the PI and his collaborators successfully investigated other structural aspects for group von Neumann algebras, including tensor decompositions, product rigidity, and solidity. He also investigated new rigidity properties for von Neumann algebras of group actions. Some of these results and methods have stirred significant subsequent developments from other researchers in the field.

The research avenues investigated in this project bring new insight to other branches of Mathematics, particularly, group theory, C*-algebras, continuous model theory and ergodic theory. Some of the methods developed by the PI and his collaborators unveiled a rich interplay of ideas and techniques between deformation/rigidity theory and the aforementioned areas. Moreover, the open problems and the research carried out from the project generated a host of open questions in group theory and logic, triggering new studies from mathematicians within these areas.

The PI disseminated widely his research findings through publications, colloquia, seminars, and invited talks at national and international conferences and meetings. To promote the visibility of von Neumann algebras and related areas the PI organized conferences at mathematical institutes (e.g. American Institute of Mathematics) and multiple, year-long seminars at his home institution. At University of Iowa, he designed and conducted four new, year-long courses on topics covering von Neumann algebras, dynamics, and geometric group theory. Through these classes he was able to attract five new graduate students to this research. Four of these students (including two underrepresented minorities) wrote exciting PhD dissertations providing complete solutions to several of the open problems presented in this project. These achievements earned one of them a prestigious Presidential Postdoctoral Fellowship at UCLA and another a tenure-track position in a research university in Thailand. A fifth student is also currently completing his PhD dissertation on an open problem related with this proposal and is ready to graduate this year. While training the Iowa team for the Putnam competition, the PI has recruited a senior undergraduate student and supervised him on a project that arose from this project. He is now pursuing his PhD degree at UCLA working in von Neumann algebras under the under the supervision of S. Popa. During the award period the PI supervised one postdoctoral fellow and research theme from the proposal served as a pipeline of problems for our joint papers.

A significant portion of the funds from the project were used to support the travel of the PI, his PhD students and postdoctoral mentees participation to conferences and other mathematical events, both in the US and abroad. Funds were also used to defray travel expenses for more than twenty operator algebras speakers in the Mathematical Colloquium and Operator Theory Seminar at the University of Iowa.
